content: Hey, I'm back with an update. I survived the hike and sent out my first few internship applications.
That's a huge week, Ethan! Congrats on both fronts. How was the hike? Did it help clear your head?
It was amazing. The air was crisp, and the view from the summit was totally worth the climb. I felt completely disconnected from all the school and career stress. I felt genuinely calm.
That sounds perfect. And then you dove right back into the stress by sending out applications. How does that part feel?
Honestly, pretty nerve-wracking. Hitting 'submit' is terrifying. But also exciting. It makes my career goals feel more real, like you said.
It's a mix of nerves and excitement for sure. Did you end up applying for those backend-focused roles?
Yep, mostly backend software engineering roles. I polished my resume and highlighted my note-taking app project, mentioning the PostgreSQL backend and the new UI features.
Smart move. Speaking of which, how did the UI tinkering go? Did you implement that breakthrough idea?
I did! I added keyboard shortcuts for creating and tagging notes. It was a fun challenge with JavaScript event listeners, and it makes the app so much faster to use. I'm all about efficiency.
That's an awesome feature! It shows you think about user experience and efficiency, even if you prefer the backend. That'll look great to recruiters.
I hope so. The whole application process is making me a bit tense, though. I've been playing a lot more piano at night to keep my mind off waiting for replies.
Leaning on your established coping mechanisms is good. The piano seems to be a reliable way for you to decompress.
It is. The structured, mathematical nature of classical music is the opposite of the chaos and uncertainty of job hunting.
That's a great way to put it. Besides the applications, how's the semester wrapping up? Finals must be on the horizon.

They are, about three weeks out. I'm trying not to think about it, but the final projects are already piling up. I feel like my motivation is taking a serious hit. It's classic end-of-semester burnout.
End-of-semester burnout is incredibly real, especially when you're also juggling internship stress. What usually helps you get through that final push?

Breaking things down into super small, manageable tasks. If I can just get one tiny function written or one paragraph of a paper drafted, the progress helps motivate me to do the next. And coffee. Lots and lots of coffee.
The 'small wins' strategy is very effective. It keeps you from getting overwhelmed by the sheer scale of it all.
Exactly. My support network helps too. My friends and I are planning a big 'end of finals' celebration to have something to look forward to.
Having a light at the end of the tunnel is a great motivator. What are you guys thinking of doing?
We're planning a weekend trip to the mountains. No computers, just hiking, a campfire, and relaxing. It's the ultimate reward to keep us going.
That sounds like an incredible goal to work towards. It ties back nicely to your newfound enjoyment of hiking.
Yeah, it's become a really important activity for my mental health. A way to truly unplug.
That's great that you've identified that. Speaking of unplugging, have you had any time for your other escapes, like sci-fi or Stardew Valley?
Not much Stardew Valley, it's too much of a time sink right now. But I did just finish the book series 'The Expanse' is based on. The science is so grounded and realistic, I loved it.
Oh, so you're into hard sci-fi, where the science is plausible. That makes sense given your analytical, logic-driven mindset.
Totally. It's more immersive for me when it feels like it could actually happen. Fantasy with dragons and magic doesn't grab me in the same way.
That's a cool distinction. Well, Ethan, it sounds like you have a stressful but well-managed few weeks ahead of you. Remember that 'small wins' strategy.
Will do. It's just a final sprint. Thanks for listening.
Of course. Keep me posted on how the applications and the final projects go. You've got this.
Thanks. I'll talk to you when I come up for air.
Looking forward to it. Good luck!
Later.
See you.
